title: 113_s1733
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Exploitation Through Trafficking Act of 2013" and includes a National Safe Harbor Law. The "Stop Exploitation Through Trafficking Act of 2013" defines key terms such as commercial sex act, minor, severe form of trafficking in persons, and State. It requires each State to have legislation in effect three years after enactment to address trafficking issues. Each State must have legislation treating minors involved in commercial sex acts as trafficking victims, discouraging prosecution for related offenses, and promoting diversion to child protection services. Failure to comply may result in the withholding of Byrne Justice Assistance Grant funds by the Attorney General. During a 3-year period after the enactment of this Act, a percentage of funds allocated to the State under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 will be withheld: 3% in the first year, 4% in the second year, and 5% in subsequent years. Any funds not allocated to a State under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 due to non-compliance will be reallocated to compliant States. SEC. 3. CIVIL REMEDIES. Amends Section 1595(a) of title 18, United States Code by inserting "treble" before "damages". SEC. 4. RESTITUTION. The Attorney General must establish a process to collect and analyze data on mandatory restitution orders under section 1593 of title 18, United States Code. The process must ensure data collection for each offense charged under chapter 77 and track enforcement of each restitution order. An amendment to the Victims Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 requires an annual report on these matters. The Attorney General must collect and analyze data on mandatory restitution orders under section 1593 of title 18, US Code. An amendment to the Victims Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 requires an annual report including data from the Stop Exploitation Through Trafficking Act of 2013 for reports after January 1, 2015. SEC. 5. NATIONAL HUMAN TRAFFICKING HOTLINE. Section 107(b)(2) of the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include grants for a national communication system to assist victims of trafficking in persons in communicating with service providers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prioritize grant applicants with experience in providing telephone services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prioritize grant applicants with experience in providing telephone services to victims of severe forms of trafficking in persons. SEC. 6. JOB CORPS ELIGIBILITY. Amends the Workforce Investment Act to include victims of severe trafficking in persons as eligible for Job Corps without demonstrating eligibility. SEC. 7. ESTABLISHING A NATIONAL STRATEGY TO COMBAT HUMAN TRAFFICKING. The Attorney General is required to implement and maintain a National Strategy for Combating Human Trafficking, which includes integrated efforts at all levels of law enforcement to investigate and prosecute human trafficking cases. This involves partnerships between United States attorneys and other law enforcement agencies, as well as the development of district-specific strategic plans. The National Strategy for Combating Human Trafficking includes the prosecution of human trafficking crimes, strategies to rescue victims, appointment of dedicated prosecutors, participation in training programs, and collaboration with task forces. The Department of Justice aims to enhance coordination and cooperation in human trafficking investigations among various entities, including United States attorneys, the Human Trafficking Prosecution Unit, the Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. This includes timely notification of sex or labor trafficking investigations opened by the FBI. The Department of Justice aims to enhance coordination and cooperation in human trafficking investigations among various entities, including the FBI, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Labor, and Human Smuggling and Trafficking Center. This includes reporting investigations in the annual report required by the Victims Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000. Interagency coordination is crucial for preventing, investigating, and apprehending individuals involved in human trafficking. The Department of Justice coordinates with various federal agencies to combat human trafficking, including the Department of Homeland Security, Department of Labor, Department of State, Department of Health and Human Services, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and other appropriate agencies. The Attorney General sets measurable objectives and long-term goals for combating human trafficking. Annual budget priorities and federal efforts are dedicated to preventing and combating human trafficking, including resources for the Human Trafficking Prosecution Unit, Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, FBI, and other entities focused on combating exploitation of adults and children. The ongoing assessment of future trends, challenges, and opportunities in combating human trafficking includes new investigative strategies, techniques, and technologies to enhance federal, state, local, and tribal efforts. Cooperation between private sector entities, organizations, and federal agencies is encouraged to combat human trafficking, involving state, local, and tribal government agencies as needed. SEC. 8. ENHANCING LAW ENFORCEMENT COORDINATION. Section 105(d)(7) of the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include reporting requirements for sex and labor trafficking investigations opened by various federal agencies under specific sections of the United States Code, as well as the number of these investigations reported to relevant authorities. The Trafficking Prosecution Unit in the Civil Rights Division and the Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section in the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice are involved in investigating sex and labor trafficking cases. SEC. 9. SEX OFFENDER REGISTRY. Amends the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act to include more severe offenses like sex trafficking against minors. SEC. 10. SEVERABILITY. SEC. 10. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed invalid, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.
